quizzes.title: Angular Fundamentals Assessment
quizzes.description: Test your understanding of Angular core concepts

questions.question: What is the purpose of Angular's dependency injection system?
options: To provide services and dependencies to components
questions.explanation: Dependency Injection is a design pattern used to provide instances of classes (services) to components that need them, promoting reusability and testability.

questions.question: Standalone components in Angular require NgModules to work.
questions.explanation: Standalone components are self-contained and don't require NgModules. They import their dependencies directly.

questions.question: Which decorator is used to create a reusable component in Angular?
questions.explanation: @Component() is the decorator used to define Angular components.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Angular Signals?
questions.explanation: Signals provide a reactive way to manage state in Angular applications, automatically updating the UI when values change.

questions.question: Reactive Forms in Angular use the FormBuilder service to create form controls.
questions.explanation: FormBuilder is a service that provides convenient methods for creating FormGroup and FormControl instances.

questions.question: Which lifecycle hook is called when a component is initialized?
questions.explanation: ngOnInit() is called once after the first ngOnChanges() and is used for component initialization logic.

questions.question: The @if and @for syntax in Angular templates is the new control flow syntax introduced in Angular 17.
questions.explanation: Angular 17 introduced a new built-in control flow syntax with @if, @for, and @switch, which is more performant than *ngIf and *ngFor.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Angular's HttpClient?
options: To make HTTP requests to backend APIs
questions.explanation: HttpClient is Angular's service for making HTTP requests to communicate with backend APIs.

questions.question: Which of the following is used to protect routes in Angular?
questions.explanation: Route Guards (like CanActivate, CanDeactivate) are used to control access to routes based on conditions.

questions.question: Angular services should be decorated with @Injectable() to be used with dependency injection.
questions.explanation: The @Injectable() decorator marks a class as available for dependency injection.

quizzes.title: Product Analysis Fundamentals Quiz
quizzes.description: Assess your understanding of product analysis concepts

questions.question: What is the primary goal of product analysis?
options: To understand user needs and improve product value
questions.explanation: Product analysis focuses on understanding user needs, market trends, and data to make informed decisions that improve product value.

questions.question: User personas are fictional representations of your target users based on research and data.
questions.explanation: User personas help teams empathize with users and make user-centered decisions.

questions.question: Which metric measures how many users continue to use a product over time?
questions.explanation: Retention rate measures the percentage of users who return to use the product after their first visit.

questions.question: What is an MVP (Minimum Viable Product)?
options: A fully featured product ready for market
A product with just enough features to gather validated learning
The most valuable player in product team
questions.explanation: An MVP is a version of the product with just enough features to be usable by early customers who can provide feedback for future development.

questions.question: A/B testing is a method to compare two versions of a feature to see which performs better.
questions.explanation: A/B testing involves showing different versions to different user segments and measuring which performs better on key metrics.

questions.question: What does 'Product-Market Fit' mean?
options: When the product fits in the market budget
When the product satisfies a strong market demand
When the product team fits the company culture
When the product matches competitor features
questions.explanation: Product-Market Fit means creating a product that satisfies a strong market demand and solves a real problem for users.

questions.question: User stories follow the format: 'As a [user type], I want [goal] so that [reason]'.
questions.explanation: This format helps teams understand who the feature is for, what they want to do, and why it matters.

questions.question: Which framework helps prioritize features based on value and effort?
questions.explanation: RICE (Reach, Impact, Confidence, Effort) framework helps prioritize features by scoring them on these dimensions.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a product roadmap?
options: To show the geographic locations of users
To outline the vision and direction of the product over time
questions.explanation: A product roadmap communicates the strategic direction and planned evolution of the product.

questions.question: Qualitative data (like user interviews) is more important than quantitative data (like analytics).
questions.explanation: Both qualitative and quantitative data are important. Qualitative helps understand 'why', while quantitative helps understand 'what' and 'how much'.

quizzes.title: Advanced Angular Patterns Assessment
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of advanced Angular concepts and patterns

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of using Angular Signals?
options: Fine-grained reactive state management with automatic UI updates
questions.explanation: Signals enable granular reactivity, tracking state usage precisely to optimize rendering and update only affected UI parts automatically, unlike traditional change detection.

questions.question: OnPush change detection strategy improves performance.
questions.explanation: OnPush limits checks to input reference changes or events, skipping unnecessary change detection cycles and boosting performance in complex apps.

questions.question: Angular Signals integrate seamlessly with RxJS for advanced reactivity.
questions.explanation: Signals complement RxJS by providing synchronous reactivity that can combine with observables for hybrid reactive patterns in performance-critical apps.

questions.question: Using trackBy with ngFor is a key RxJS performance pattern.
questions.explanation: trackBy optimizes ngFor by reusing DOM elements based on unique keys during list changes, reducing recreations; it's a core performance technique alongside RxJS usage.

questions.question: Signals eliminate the need for manual change detection entirely.
options: They enable fine-grained automatic updates without manual intervention
questions.explanation: Signals allow Angular to automatically detect and update only dependent UI via pull-based reactivity, minimizing manual change detection needs.

quizzes.title: User Research Methods Assessment
quizzes.description: Evaluate your understanding of user research techniques

questions.question: User interviews are a qualitative method for in-depth insights.
questions.explanation: User interviews involve open-ended discussions to uncover experiences, needs, and behaviors that surveys might miss.

questions.question: Which is NOT a common usability testing method?
questions.explanation: Usability testing methods like lab, contextual, and guerrilla focus on observing user interactions; code review is a development practice, not research.

questions.question: Research planning should start with defining goals and stage.
questions.explanation: Effective planning maps goals to methods—generative (e.g., interviews) early, evaluative (e.g., A/B tests) later—for targeted insights.

questions.question: Moderated usability testing provides richer feedback than unmoderated.
questions.explanation: Moderated sessions allow real-time probing and guidance, yielding deeper qualitative insights compared to independent unmoderated tests.

questions.question: Tree testing evaluates information architecture.
questions.explanation: Tree testing assesses navigation and labeling by having users find items in a site map prototype without visuals.

quizzes.title: RxJS Mastery Assessment
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of advanced RxJS patterns and error handling

questions.question: catchError operator handles errors by replacing with fallback.
questions.explanation: catchError catches errors in the observable chain and maps them to a new observable, like a fallback value or rethrow.

questions.question: retry operator resubscribes on error a specified number of times.
questions.explanation: retry(n) automatically retries failed emissions up to n times, ideal for transient errors like network issues.

questions.question: Observables must be subscribed to emit values.
questions.explanation: Observables are lazy; subscription triggers execution and value emission to observers.

questions.question: finalize executes regardless of complete or error.
questions.explanation: finalize runs cleanup code (e.g., unsubscribes) on completion, error, or unsubscription.

questions.question: Higher-order observables require flattening operators like switchMap.
questions.explanation: Operators returning observables (e.g., switchMap) flatten inner streams to manage multiple observables effectively.

quizzes.title: Requirements Engineering Assessment
quizzes.description: Evaluate your mastery of requirements engineering practices

questions.question: SRS includes both functional and non-functional requirements.
questions.explanation: SRS details what the system does (functional) and qualities like performance, security (non-functional).

questions.question: Traceability links requirements to design and tests.
questions.explanation: Bidirectional traceability ensures coverage, verifies implementation, and tracks changes across artifacts.

questions.question: Change management starts with identification and evaluation.
questions.explanation: Process captures requests, assesses impact, approves, implements, and documents to control scope creep.

questions.question: Performance requirements in SRS are always dynamic.
questions.explanation: Dynamic constraints execution behavior (e.g., response time); static do not (e.g., memory limits).

questions.question: Requirements documentation must be complete and verifiable.
questions.explanation: Good SRS is unambiguous, complete, verifiable, and traceable for successful development and validation.

quizzes.title: Java Fundamentals Assessment
quizzes.description: Test your understanding of Java basics and OOP

questions.question: What is the main purpose of the Java Virtual Machine (JVM)?
options: To execute Java bytecode across different platforms
questions.explanation: The JVM executes Java bytecode, enabling Java's 'write once, run anywhere' capability by providing platform independence.

questions.question: In Java, all methods must return a value.
questions.explanation: Methods with void return type don't return any value. Only methods with specific return types must return a value.

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid way to declare a variable in Java?
questions.explanation: Variable names must start with a letter, underscore, or dollar sign, and cannot contain spaces or hyphens. 'int number;' is the correct syntax.

questions.question: Java supports multiple inheritance through classes.
questions.explanation: Java does not support multiple inheritance with classes to avoid complexity. However, it supports multiple inheritance through interfaces.

questions.question: What is encapsulation in Java?
options: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit
questions.explanation: Encapsulation is wrapping data and code together in a single unit (class), typically using access modifiers to hide internal state.

quizzes.title: Advanced Java Assessment
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of advanced Java concepts

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Executor framework in Java?
options: To manage thread lifecycle and thread pooling efficiently
questions.explanation: The Executor framework provides high-level thread management, including thread pools, making concurrent programming easier and more efficient.

questions.question: Java Streams can only be used with collections.
questions.explanation: Streams can be created from various sources including collections, arrays, I/O channels, and even generated on-the-fly using Stream.generate() or Stream.iterate().

questions.question: Which keyword is used to define a lambda expression parameter that shouldn't be changed?
questions.explanation: Lambda expressions can only access local variables that are final or effectively final to ensure thread safety and predictability.

questions.question: synchronized keyword in Java ensures that only one thread can execute a synchronized method at a time across all instances.
questions.explanation: Synchronized instance methods lock the object instance, allowing one thread per instance. For class-level locking, use synchronized static methods or synchronized(ClassName.class).

questions.question: What does the Stream.collect() method do?
options: Maps stream elements to new values
Accumulates stream elements into a result container
questions.explanation: collect() is a terminal operation that accumulates stream elements into a mutable result container like a List, Set, or Map using a Collector.

questions.question: What is the difference between a list and a tuple in Python?
options: Lists are mutable, tuples are immutable
questions.explanation: The key difference is mutability: lists can be modified after creation (mutable), while tuples cannot be changed once created (immutable).

questions.question: Python uses indentation to define code blocks.
questions.explanation: Unlike many languages that use braces, Python uses indentation (spaces or tabs) to define code blocks, making code more readable.

questions.question: Which Python data structure would you use to store unique values?
questions.explanation: A set is an unordered collection of unique elements. It automatically removes duplicates and provides fast membership testing.

questions.question: In Python, variables must be declared with a specific type before use.
questions.explanation: Python is dynamically typed, so you don't need to declare variable types explicitly. The type is inferred from the assigned value.

questions.question: What does the 'range(5)' function return in Python 3?
questions.explanation: In Python 3, range() returns a range object (an immutable sequence type) rather than a list, making it more memory efficient.

questions.question: What is a decorator in Python?
options: A function that adds visual styling to output
A function that modifies or enhances another function or class
questions.explanation: Decorators are functions that take another function as input and extend its behavior without modifying its source code, using the @decorator syntax.

questions.question: Python generators are more memory efficient than lists for large sequences.
questions.explanation: Generators use lazy evaluation, yielding one item at a time, while lists store all items in memory at once. This makes generators much more memory efficient.

questions.question: What keyword is used to define a coroutine in Python?
questions.explanation: Coroutines are defined using 'async def', enabling asynchronous programming with await expressions inside the function.

questions.question: The GIL (Global Interpreter Lock) in Python prevents true parallel execution of Python threads.
questions.explanation: The GIL allows only one thread to execute Python bytecode at a time, preventing true parallelism in CPU-bound tasks (though I/O-bound tasks can still benefit from threading).

questions.question: What is the purpose of '__init__' method in a Python class?
options: To initialize object attributes when an instance is created
questions.explanation: __init__ is the constructor method that initializes new object instances, setting up initial attribute values and performing setup operations.

quizzes.title: Computer Fundamentals Assessment
quizzes.description: Test your understanding of computer basics

questions.question: What is the primary function of RAM in a computer?
options: Temporary storage for data and programs currently in use
questions.explanation: RAM (Random Access Memory) provides fast, temporary storage for data and programs that the CPU is actively using. It's volatile and loses data when power is off.

questions.question: The CPU (Central Processing Unit) is responsible for storing all your files and documents.
questions.explanation: The CPU processes instructions and performs calculations. File storage is handled by storage devices like hard drives or SSDs.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an operating system?
questions.explanation: Windows 11 is an operating system that manages hardware and software resources. The others are application software that run on top of an OS.

questions.question: SSD (Solid State Drive) is faster than traditional HDD (Hard Disk Drive).
questions.explanation: SSDs use flash memory with no moving parts, providing much faster read/write speeds and lower latency compared to HDDs which use spinning magnetic platters.

questions.question: What does 'bit' stand for in computer terms?
questions.explanation: A bit (binary digit) is the smallest unit of data in computing, representing either 0 or 1. Eight bits make up one byte.

questions.question: What is a variable in programming?
options: A fixed value that never changes
A container for storing data values
questions.explanation: A variable is a named container that stores data values which can be referenced and manipulated in a program. The value can change during program execution.

questions.question: A 'for loop' is used to execute code repeatedly based on a condition.
questions.explanation: A for loop iterates over a sequence or repeats code a specific number of times, typically using a counter or iterator.

questions.question: What is the purpose of an 'if statement' in programming?
options: To make decisions and execute code based on conditions
questions.explanation: An if statement allows conditional execution - code runs only when a specified condition is true, enabling decision-making in programs.

questions.question: Functions help make code more modular and reusable.
questions.explanation: Functions encapsulate reusable blocks of code that perform specific tasks, making programs more organized, maintainable, and reducing code duplication.

questions.question: What is an algorithm?
options: A step-by-step procedure to solve a problem
questions.explanation: An algorithm is a finite sequence of well-defined instructions to solve a problem or perform a computation. It's language-independent and focuses on the logic.
